questions.text: Congenital anomaly as shown in pic is due to involvement of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Left 6th arch artery

Left 6th arch artery. The image illustrates a right aortic arch with a persistent left-sided component (likely a ligamentum arteriosum or ductus arteriosus) connecting to the descending aorta, thereby forming a complete vascular ring around the trachea and esophagus. This specific configuration, a right aortic arch with a left vascular component completing the ring, arises from the abnormal development where the right 4th aortic arch forms the main aortic arch, and the left 6th aortic arch artery (which normally forms the ductus arteriosus and later ligamentum arteriosum) persists in such a way that it completes the encirclement. Therefore, the persistence and specific arrangement involving the left 6th arch artery are crucial for the formation of the depicted congenital anomaly.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with complaints of urinary urgency, frequency, and urge incontinence. After excluding other causes, she is diagnosed with overactive bladder (OAB). Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for symptom control in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Oxybutynin 

Explanation: 

• Overactive bladder (OAB) is treated with antimuscarinic agents like oxybutynin, which inhibit M3 receptors on the detrusor muscle, reducing involuntary contractions. 

Other options: 

• Bethanechol: Muscarinic agonist, used in atonic bladder
(urinary retention).

• Tamsulosin: ?1-blocker, used in BPH to relax the bladder neck and prostate. 

• Finasteride: 5?-reductase inhibitor, shrinks prostate size over months (BPH).

questions.text: A 2-year-old child suspected of a genetic disorder is diagnosed of Leukaemia. Karyotype is as given below. Likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

AML

The karyotype provided clearly shows Trisomy 21, meaning there are three copies of chromosome 21 instead of the usual two. This chromosomal abnormality is diagnostic of Down Syndrome. Children with Down Syndrome have a significantly increased risk of developing leukemia compared to the general population. Among the types of leukemia, there is a particularly strong association between Down Syndrome and Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML), especially the subtype acute megakaryoblastic leukemia (AMKL), which often presents in very young children with Trisomy 21. While B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (B-ALL) also has an increased incidence in Down Syndrome, the association with AML is even more pronounced and specific in this age group, making B. AML the most likely diagnosis given the karyotype.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with primary open-angle glaucoma is prescribed Netarsudil. Which of the following best describes its mechanism of action and the most common adverse effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Inhibits rho kinase to enhance trabecular outflow; conjunctival hyperemia Netarsudil is a Rho kinase (ROCK) inhibitor, a new class of drugs for glaucoma. It enhances trabecular meshwork outflow, lowering intraocular pressure. Most common side effect: conjunctival hyperemia (red eye). Other options explained: A: Latanoprost (prostaglandin analog) increases uveoscleral outflow, causes iris pigmentation. B: Timolol (beta-blocker), causes dry eyes, bronchospasm. D: Acetazolamide (carbonic anhydrase inhibitor), causes metabolic acidosis, renal stones.

questions.text: Which of the following antidepressants is a norepinephrine-dopamine reuptake inhibitor and is associated with weight neutrality and smoking cessation benefit?
questions.solution:

• Mirtazapine:
Causes sedation and weight gain. 

• Duloxetine: SNRI. 

• Sertraline: SSRI.

questions.text: Which of the following points in the cardiac muscle action potential is close to the equilibrium potential of potassium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

At rest the cell membrane is maximally permeable to potassium.

Therefore, the potential at A will be the closest to the equilibrium potential of potassium. The upstroke of the cardiac action potential is due to the influx of sodium through voltage gated sodium channels. Point B will, therefore, be closest to the equilibrium potential of sodium.

questions.text: A patients Coagulation profile is as follows platelet count 45000, BT 12 min, CT 8 min, PT 22 seconds, APTT 65 seconds, TT 22 seconds, Fibrinogen levels are low. Most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

DIC (Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation). This diagnosis is indicated by the comprehensive abnormalities in the patient's coagulation profile. DIC is a serious condition characterized by widespread activation of the clotting cascade, leading to the formation of microthrombi throughout the body, which then consumes platelets and clotting factors at an accelerated rate. This consumption results in:

1. Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) and prolonged bleeding time, as seen in the patient (platelet count 45,000, BT 12 min).

2. Depletion of coagulation factors, leading to prolonged PT and APTT (PT 22 seconds, APTT 65 seconds).

3. Consumption of fibrinogen, resulting in low fibrinogen levels and a prolonged Thrombin Time (TT) (TT 22 seconds, Fibrinogen low).
The combination of these findings, indicating both impaired clot formation and consumption of clotting components, is pathognomonic for DIC.

questions.text: A 48-year-old patient with heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia is already on maximumdose atorvastatin and ezetimibe, but LDL-C remains high. The physician considers adding alirocumab. Which of the following is a correct statement about alirocumab mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

(It enhances LDL receptor recycling) Alirocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor, a class of monoclonal antibodies used to significantly lower LDL-C, especially in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established ASCVD not at goal on statin + ezetimibe. Mechanism of Action: 

• PCSK9 (Proprotein Convertase Subtilisin/Kexin Type 9) normally binds to LDL receptors (LDLR) on hepatocytes and promotes their degradation. 

• By inhibiting PCSK9, alirocumab prevents this degradation, thereby: o Increasing the number of LDL receptors on the liver surface. o Enhancing clearance of LDL-C from the bloodstream. Thus, alirocumab enhances LDL receptor recycling, making
option D the correct answer. 

Incorrect options: 

• A. It increases the expression of HMG-CoA reductase HMG-CoA reductase is the enzyme inhibited by statins, not increased by PCSK9 inhibitors. 

• B. It is an inhibitor of ATP-citrate lyase This describes bempedoic acid, not alirocumab. 

• C. It is the oral NPC1L1 inhibitor This refers to ezetimibe, which blocks cholesterol absorption in the intestine via NPC1L1.

questions.text:
Read the Following statements regarding Action 

A. Triceps Brachii – Extension at Elbow 

B. Supraspinatus – Initiation of Abduction of shoulder 

C. Pectoralis major – Flexion, Adduction & Medial Rotation of shoulder 

D. Lumbricals – MCP Flexion, IP Extension
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

All are correct

A. Triceps Brachii - Extension at Elbow: The triceps brachii is the primary extensor muscle of the elbow joint. This statement is correct.

B. Supraspinatus - Initiation of Abduction of shoulder: The supraspinatus muscle is part of the rotator cuff and is responsible for initiating abduction (lifting the arm away from the body) at the shoulder joint, up to approximately 15-20 degrees. This statement is correct.

C. Pectoralis major - Flexion, Adduction & Medial Rotation of shoulder: The pectoralis major muscle has multiple actions on the shoulder joint, including flexion (bringing the arm forward), adduction (bringing the arm towards the body), and medial (internal) rotation. This statement is correct.

D. Lumbricals - MCP Flexion, IP Extension: The lumbrical muscles of the hand are unique in their action. They originate from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons and insert into the extensor expansions. This allows them to flex the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extend the interphalangeal (IP) joints (both proximal and distal). This statement is correct.

questions.text: 55 years old male presenting with periorbital edema, facial puffiness and massive proteinuria Renal biopsy has revealed following features under Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF) and electron microscopy (EM) as shown in given picture. All of the following are true regarding this condition except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mesangial deposits will be seen on EM.

This statement is false for Membranous Nephropathy. The defining feature of Membranous Nephropathy on electron microscopy is the presence of electron-dense immune complex deposits located in the subepithelial space (between the glomerular basement membrane and the podocytes), often with new basement membrane material ("spikes") forming around them. Mesangial deposits are characteristic of other glomerular diseases, such as IgA nephropathy or some forms of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, but not Membranous Nephropathy.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man with atrial fibrillation is brought to the emergency department after a fall, with signs of intracranial hemorrhage on CT scan. He was recently started on dabigatran for stroke prophylaxis. Which of the following agents is the most appropriate antidote to reverse his anticoagulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Idarucizumab 

Explanation: • Dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor (oral anticoagulant). 

• Idarucizumab is a monoclonal antibody fragment that specifically binds to and neutralizes dabigatran — used in life-threatening bleeding or urgent surgery. 

Other options: 

• Protamine sulfate: Reverses heparin. 

• Vitamin K: Antidote for warfarin. 

• Andexanet alfa: Used for Factor Xa inhibitors like rivaroxaban/apixaban.

questions.text: FNAC of paraaortic mass in a 10-year-old child with fever and weight loss is as follows. Which of the following marker best fits into this case
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

CD20+, CD10+, Tdt-

CD20+, CD10+, TdT-. The image provided depicts cells with features highly characteristic of Burkitt Lymphoma, including uniform medium-sized cells with basophilic cytoplasm and often prominent nucleoli, alongside tingible body macrophages (giving a "starry sky" appearance, though not fully captured). In a 10-year-old child with a paraaortic mass, fever, and weight loss, an aggressive lymphoma is strongly suspected. Burkitt lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell lymphoma that typically expresses CD20 (a B-cell marker) and CD10 (a germinal center marker). Crucially, unlike precursor B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (B-ALL/LBL), Burkitt lymphoma is a mature B-cell neoplasm and is thus TdT-negative. Therefore, the immunophenotype CD20+, CD10+, TdT- best fits the likely diagnosis of Burkitt Lymphoma.

questions.text: Injury to lateral part of dorsal column at the cervical region results in loss of proprioception in ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Ipsilateral upper limb

Ipsilateral upper limb. The dorsal column pathway is responsible for proprioception, and its fibers ascend on the same side of the spinal cord (ipsilaterally) before crossing in the medulla. In the cervical region, the dorsal column is divided into the fasciculus gracilis (medial, for lower body) and the fasciculus cuneatus (lateral, for upper body). Therefore, an injury to the lateral part of the dorsal column in the cervical region specifically affects the fasciculus cuneatus, leading to a loss of proprioception in the ipsilateral upper limb.

questions.text:
A new described neurological disorder is found to affect multiple members in the family over 3 generations. In the first generation which consisted of two sisters and one brother all were found to be affected. In the second generation all children of first generation sisters were affected but children
of sons were spared. In the third generation all children of second generation women were affected but not the children of second generation men. The mode of inheritance is -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Mitochondrial inheritance. 

The pattern described is characterized by affected mothers transmitting the disorder to all of their children (both sons and daughters), while affected fathers do not transmit the disorder to any of their children. This strict maternal-only inheritance to all offspring, and the absence of paternal transmission, is the hallmark feature of mitochondrial disorders. The scenario explicitly states that "all children of first generation sisters were affected but children of sons were spared" in the second generation, and the same pattern repeated in the third generation, perfectly aligning with mitochondrial inheritance.

choices.text: Transport of glucose from the intestinal lumen into intestinal epithelial cell is by secondary active co-transport
Transport of glucose into adipocytes is by facilitated diffusion
Movement of Ca++ from cardiac muscle cell to the ECF during muscle relaxation is by Na+-dependent counter transport
Movement of K+ ions out of the nerve cell during the downstroke phase of the action potential is by facilitated diffusion

questions.text:
Given below are four examples of transport across the cell membrane with the type of transport.

Which of the following is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the intestinal epithelial cells is by Na+- glucose co-transport, an example of secondary active co-transport.

Glucose is transported into adipocytes by insulin-dependent facilitated diffusion.

Movement of Ca++ from cardiac muscle cell to the ECF during muscle relaxation is by Na+-Ca++ antiport, which is an example of secondary active counter transport. During the repolarization phase of the action potential opening of voltage gated potassium channels allows the efflux of potassium. Transport through channels is an example of simple diffusion.

questions.text: While playing football, the ball hits a 12-year-old boy on his shin with considerable force. He sits on the ground and starts rubbing the area to reduce the pain. Inhibition of pain signals by tactile stimulation of the skin is mediated by which type of afferent neurons from the mechanoreceptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aβ

When the boy rubs his shin, he is activating mechanoreceptors in the skin. These mechanoreceptors transmit tactile information via large, fast-conducting Aβ afferent fibers. According to the Gate Control Theory of Pain, these Aβ fibers, upon activation, can presynaptically inhibit the transmission of pain signals carried by slower C and Aδ fibers in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. By "closing the gate" to pain signals, the rubbing action effectively reduces the perception of pain.

By rubbing the area touch receptors are stimulated. Touch sensation carried by type Aβ fibres causes
a pre-synaptic inhibition of the pain pathway in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord (Gate control theory
of Melzac and Wall).

choices.text: Rhodamine stain is used for diagnosis
Mallory denk bodies are seen on liver biopsy

questions.text: A 23-year-old male with chronic liver disease was evaluated and found to be having findings given below. This condition is most likely to be associated with which of the following alterations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Mallory denk bodies are seen on liver biopsy

The image displays a Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring, which is a hallmark sign of Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder of copper metabolism. The correct option is B. Mallory-Denk bodies are seen on liver biopsy. While often associated with alcoholic liver disease, Mallory-Denk bodies are also a recognized histological finding in the liver biopsies of patients with Wilson's disease. Their presence indicates hepatocyte injury and can be observed alongside other features like steatosis, inflammation, or cirrhosis. This makes statement B a true pathological association with the condition indicated by the KF ring.

questions.text: A 32-year-old software engineer, vegetarian by diet undergoes annual health checkup CBC shows Hb 11, MCH 24, MCV 65, RBC count is 5.5 million. What should be done next
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

HPLC. 

While microcytic anemia (low MCV 65, MCH 24) can be caused by iron deficiency, the co-occurrence of a relatively high red blood cell count (5.5 million) is a critical clue. This specific combination (low MCV with a normal or elevated RBC count) is highly characteristic of a thalassemia trait (e.g., alpha or beta thalassemia minor), where the bone marrow compensates for defective hemoglobin synthesis by producing more, but smaller, red blood cells. In contrast, iron deficiency anemia typically presents with a low MCV but a normal or low RBC count. Therefore, given this strong indicator for thalassemia, HPLC (High-Performance Liquid Chromatography) is the most direct and definitive next step to identify abnormal hemoglobin variants and confirm a thalassemia diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient with H/O pain in both legs while taking long walk, He has developed toe gangrene and he admits to have Erectile dysfunction. Which of the following artery is involved in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Aorto iliac Junction

Aorto-iliac Junction. This is because the constellation of symptoms—pain in both legs while walking (bilateral claudication), toe gangrene, and erectile dysfunction—is highly characteristic of Leriche syndrome, which is caused by occlusive disease at the aorto-iliac bifurcation. An obstruction at this junction impairs blood flow to both common iliac arteries, subsequently affecting the external iliac arteries (supplying the legs, leading to claudication and gangrene) and the internal iliac arteries (which branch to supply the pelvic organs, including the penis, thereby causing erectile dysfunction). This singular, proximal blockage efficiently explains all the patient's severe and bilateral symptoms, making it the most probable diagnosis compared to isolated or unilateral arterial involvement.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male smoker presents with cough, hemoptysis and weight loss. X ray shows calcified lesions in the lung and hilar lymph nodes. Serum calcium is increased. Biopsy from the lung lesion is as follows which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sarcoidosis. Histology shows discrete non necrotising granulomas this along with hypercalcemia is suggestive of sarcoidosis

Sarcoidosis. This diagnosis is most strongly supported by the combination of clinical features and the provided histology. The biopsy clearly shows multiple well-formed granulomas with no obvious evidence of caseating necrosis, which is a classic histopathological feature of sarcoidosis. Furthermore, the patient's increased serum calcium is a very strong indicator for sarcoidosis, as sarcoid granulomas contain activated macrophages that can autonomously produce calcitriol (active vitamin D), leading to hypercalcemia. While tuberculosis also causes granulomas and calcifications, it typically presents with caseating necrosis and hypercalcemia is less common and usually from a different mechanism. The calcified lesions in hilar lymph nodes are also commonly seen in sarcoidosis, often as "eggshell calcification."

questions.text: A 28-year-old athlete is diagnosed with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) after presenting with exertional syncope. Echocardiography shows asymmetric septal hypertrophy with dynamic left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Digoxin Explanation: 

• Digoxin increases myocardial contractility (positive inotrope), which can worsen the obstruction in HOCM by increasing the force of contraction against a narrowed outflow tract. 

• It is contraindicated in HOCM with obstruction. Drugs that are used in HOCM: 

• Propranolol (?-blocker): reduces heart rate and contractility ? decreases obstruction.

• Verapamil (non-dihydropyridine CCB): used if beta-blockers are contraindicated. 

• Mavacamten: a new myosin inhibitor, specifically approved for symptomatic obstructive HCM to reduce contractility and relieve obstruction. Clinical Tip: Avoid vasodilators and inotropes (like digoxin, nitrates, and dihydropyridine CCBs) in obstructive HCM.

questions.text: A 58-year-old obese man with type 2 diabetes mellitus is started on a medication that activates AMP-activated protein kinase and reduces hepatic gluconeogenesis. Which of the following adverse effects should the physician monitor closely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Lactic acidosis The drug is metformin, a biguanide. It decreases hepatic glucose production via AMPK activation. Major side effect is lactic acidosis, especially in renal or hepatic impairment. It does not cause hypoglycemia or weight gain.

questions.solution:

Methyl alcohol — Flumazenil

questions.text: A child suffering from jaundice and anemia for a long duration. Peripheral smear is as shown. True about these cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

C

Increased mechanical fragility and decreased osmotic fragility. The peripheral blood smear clearly shows the presence of sickle cells (elongated, crescent-shaped red blood cells) alongside other red blood cell abnormalities. In sickle cell disease, the abnormal hemoglobin (HbS) causes red blood cells to become rigid and prone to sickling, especially under deoxygenated conditions. These rigid and malformed sickle cells are mechanically fragile and easily destroyed as they pass through the microvasculature, leading to increased mechanical fragility. However, due to their chronic dehydration and reduced intracellular volume, sickle cells are paradoxically more resistant to osmotic lysis in hypotonic solutions compared to normal red blood cells, thus demonstrating decreased osmotic fragility. The child's long-duration jaundice and anemia are consistent with chronic hemolysis seen in sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby presented with failure to thrive and delayed milestones. On examination, he had elevated transaminases and mild hypotonia without any organomegaly. Ophthalmological examination showed a cherry red spot in the macula. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tay-Sachs disease

The above clinical scenario of an infant with failure to thrive & delayed milestones, elevated transaminases, and cherry red spot on the macula without organomegaly points to a diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease.

Tay Sach disease is an autosomal recessive disease. It occurs due to a deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. It presents with progressive neurodegeneration, foam cells (lipid-laden macrophages), a “cherry-red” spot on the macula, and developmental delay but does not have hepatosplenomegaly.

questions.text: A 29-year-old software engineer presents to the neurology clinic with a history of recurrent headaches for the past 8 months. The headaches are described as unilateral, throbbing in nature, associated with photophobia, phonophobia, and occasional vomiting. They occur around 6–8 times per month, often triggered by sleep deprivation and stress. He self-medicates with over-the-counter painkillers with partial relief. Neurological examination and MRI brain are normal. What is the most appropriate next step to prevent further episodes headache in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Flunarizine

This is a classic case of frequent migraine without aura. Since attacks are occurring >4 times per month, prophylactic treatment is warranted to reduce frequency and intensity.

Clinical Takeaway:

• Start migraine prophylaxis when:

o Attacks ≥4/month

o Poor response to abortive therapy

o Significant disability

• First-line prophylactic options: Flunarizine, Propranolol, Valproate, Amitriptyline

questions.text: Identify the type of enzyme inhibition shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Competitive inhibition (Ci) functions as a crucial biochemical process where an inhibitor molecule and a substrate vie for the same binding position at the enzyme's AS. The inhibitor occupies the AS of the enzyme by structurally imitating the substrate which prevents substrate binding. Greater inhibitor concentrations result in increased Ei yet higher substrate levels lead to decreased Ei values. Due to the effect of Ci the apparent Km value rises which demands more substrate to reach the half-maximum reaction velocity (Vmax) yet does not affect the maximum reaction rate (Vmax). Through reversible binding C-inhibitors lose their hold on the enzyme site when substrate levels reach a sufficient concentration. Irreversible inhibitors permanently change enzyme activity whereas C-inhibitors remain reversible and can be displaced

questions.text: All except the following characterize the production and actions of aldosterone in the body-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Aldosterone binds to an intracytoplasmic receptor that causes an increased synthesis of proteins, including the Na+- K+ ATPase pumps, ENaCs, K+ channels, which together increase the sodium reabsorption and potassium secretion by the tubular cells of the distal nephron.

Aldosterone also increases the H+ secretion in the distal nephron. Aldosterone secretion is stimulated by a decrease in blood volume (through the renin- angiotensin system) and by an increased plasma K+ concentration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with weight loss, easy fatigue. CBC shows Hb 9, MCH 24, MCV 70, Retic count 1.2%. which of the following should be next line of management in him
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Stool blood test. 

A 65-year-old male presenting with microcytic anemia (low Hb, MCH, MCV) and weight loss strongly suggests chronic blood loss as the cause of iron deficiency. In this age group, gastrointestinal bleeding, often due to underlying malignancy like colorectal cancer or other serious conditions such as ulcers or diverticulosis, is a primary concern. A stool blood test is a crucial, non-invasive initial step to screen for occult (hidden) blood in the stool, which would indicate ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding and necessitate further definitive investigations like endoscopy and colonoscopy to identify the source.

CD are relatively impermeable to urea, even under conditions of antidiuresis; therefore, little urea reabsorption takes place in these segments. ADH increases urea reabsorption in the medullary CD, which increases the medullary interstitial hyperosmolality.

questions.text: Biopsy from cervical lymphnode is a patient who had weight loss and lymphadenopathy is as follows. Not true about this condition
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Vincristine is used in treatment

Vincristine is used in treatment. This statement is considered not true in the context of current standard frontline therapy for Hodgkin lymphoma. While vincristine was a component of older chemotherapy regimens for Hodgkin lymphoma (e.g., MOPP regimen), the widely adopted and most common first-line treatment regimen today is ABVD (Adriamycin, Bleomycin, Vinblastine, Dacarbazine). Vinblastine, another vinca alkaloid, is used in ABVD, but vincristine is generally not. Therefore, stating that vincristine is broadly "used in treatment" as a primary agent can be misleading as it's largely superseded by vinblastine in standard contemporary protocols.

questions.text: Which of the following is an activator of gluconeogenesis but not substrate for it:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Acetyl-CoA is not a (net) substrate for gluconeogenesis since its two carbon atoms are lost as CO2 in the TCA cycle. Especially important for gluconeogenesis are Ala (in the liver), and glutamine 

Acetyl CoA is the correct option because it acts as an allosteric activator of pyruvate carboxylase, a key enzyme in gluconeogenesis, but it is not itself a substrate that can be directly converted into glucose in humans. Pyruvate carboxylase catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, the first committed step in glucose synthesis from non-carbohydrate precursors like pyruvate, lactate, and glucogenic amino acids. When acetyl CoA levels are high (often signaling abundant fatty acid oxidation), it indicates a high energy state in the cell, which favors glucose synthesis. However, the carbon atoms of acetyl CoA cannot be incorporated into glucose because the reaction catalyzed by pyruvate dehydrogenase, which forms acetyl CoA from pyruvate, is irreversible in humans, and humans lack the glyoxylate cycle to bypass this irreversibility.

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is due to defect in the biogenesis of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Peroxisomes

Zellweger syndrome is due to a defect in the biogenesis of peroxisomes.

Zellweger syndrome is also known as cerebrohepatorenal syndrome. It is caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes. This results in defective beta-oxidation of very long- chain fatty acids, defective alpha oxidation, and impaired synthesis of bile acids and plasmalogens.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with non-valvular atrial fibrillation is being considered for stroke prophylaxis. He has stage 3 chronic kidney disease (eGFR ~45 mL/min/1.73m²). Which of the following anticoagulants is most appropriate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Apixaban 

• Apixaban (a direct factor Xa inhibitor) is preferred in patients with moderate renal impairment, as it has less renal clearance compared to other NOACs like dabigatran and rivaroxaban. 

• Dabigatran is predominantly renally cleared and not preferred in CKD. 

• Enoxaparin also requires renal dose adjustment and is injectable. 

• Rivaroxaban is renally excreted to a greater extent than apixaban.

questions.text: Which fungus shows broad-based budding in tissue section?

This distinct morphological trait, where the daughter cell emerges from the parent cell with a wide connection point, is a key differentiating factor from other fungi that exhibit narrow-based budding.

questions.text: A child with fever, sore throat, sandpaper rash, and Pastia’s lines likely has:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Scarlet fever. 

The clinical presentation of a child with fever, sore throat, a characteristic "sandpaper" textured rash, and particularly the presence of Pastia's lines (linear petechial streaks in skin folds), is the classic triad of symptoms for Scarlet fever. This condition is caused by specific strains of Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Strep) that produce erythrogenic (pyrogenic) exotoxins, which are responsible for the distinctive rash and other systemic manifestations. These combined features differentiate it clearly from other childhood exanthematous diseases.

questions.text: A point in time study of blood pressure in school children to find prevalence of hypertension is an example of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Cross-sectional study

The description of the study as a "point in time study... to find prevalence of hypertension" directly aligns with the definition of a cross-sectional study. In this type of observational study, data is collected from a population at a single point in time or over a short, defined period to determine the prevalence of a disease or health condition and/or the prevalence of exposures in that population. It provides a snapshot of the health status of a community at a specific moment, which is exactly what a study to find the prevalence of hypertension in school children at a given time aims to achieve.

questions.text: Punch drunk syndrome is seen due to rupture of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Punch drunk syndrome is seen in boxers associated with sub dural hemorrhage which is caused by rupture of cortical bridging veins.

Bridging veins.

"Punch drunk syndrome," now known as Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE), is a neurodegenerative condition caused by repetitive head trauma. While CTE is a chronic condition involving diffuse brain damage and tauopathy, the impacts that cause it involve significant acceleration-deceleration forces on the brain. These forces are particularly known to cause shearing and tearing of the delicate bridging veins, which span the subdural space between the brain's surface and the dura mater. Repeated ruptures of these veins can lead to subclinical or chronic subdural hematomas and widespread microhemorrhages, contributing to the cumulative brain injury and neurodegeneration seen in CTE. Therefore, among the given vascular structures, bridging veins are most consistently associated with the type of repeated traumatic brain injury that leads to this syndrome.

questions.text: Which virus uses reverse transcriptase during replication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Hepatitis B 

Hepatitis B. Hepatitis B virus (HBV) belongs to the Hepadnaviridae family and is unique among DNA viruses in its replication strategy. During its life cycle, HBV synthesizes an RNA intermediate (pre-genomic RNA), which is then reverse transcribed back into DNA by its own virally encoded reverse transcriptase enzyme. This crucial step is essential for the formation of new viral DNA genomes that are packaged into progeny virions, making HBV a key example of a virus that utilizes reverse transcriptase for replication.

questions.text: Mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) in a 3-year-old child is 10.5 cm. This suggests:
questions.solution:

For children aged 6 months to 5 years, Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) is a rapid and effective indicator of nutritional status. According to World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines, a MUAC measurement of less than 11.5 cm indicates severe acute malnutrition (SAM). Since the 3-year-old child's MUAC is 10.5 cm, which is below this critical threshold, it points to a diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition.

This chronic condition involves progressive atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinates, leading to the characteristic changes and symptoms.

questions.text: Lead-time bias in screening refers to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Increased perception of survival due to early detection

Increased perception of survival due to early detection. Lead-time bias is a phenomenon observed in disease screening programs. It refers to the apparent prolongation of survival among individuals diagnosed through screening, even if the screening itself does not actually extend their life. This occurs because screening detects the disease earlier in its natural history, so the time interval from diagnosis to death is longer for screened individuals simply because they were diagnosed earlier, not necessarily because their lifespan was prolonged by the early detection or treatment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. Her symptoms have progressed gradually over the past 4 weeks. Which of the following signs/syndrome is seen in the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gradenigo’s syndrome

Gradenigo's syndrome. The patient's presentation of ear discharge (indicating middle ear infection or mastoiditis), deep-seated ear pain (suggesting irritation of the trigeminal nerve, specifically its ophthalmic branch), and diplopia (due to ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy) forms the classic clinical triad of Gradenigo's syndrome. This syndrome arises as a complication of otitis media or mastoiditis where the infection spreads to the petrous apex of the temporal bone, affecting the nearby trigeminal ganglion and the abducens nerve as they pass through this area.

questions.text: Which test differentiates Streptococcus pneumoniae from Viridans streptococci?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Optochin sensitivity. Both Streptococcus pneumoniae and Viridans streptococci are alpha-hemolytic, meaning they cause partial lysis of red blood cells, resulting in a greenish discoloration around their colonies on blood agar. This similarity makes it challenging to distinguish them based solely on hemolysis. However, Streptococcus pneumoniae is uniquely sensitive to optochin (ethylhydrocupreine hydrochloride), showing a clear zone of inhibition around an optochin disk. In contrast, Viridans streptococci are resistant to optochin, allowing them to grow up to the edge of the disk. This distinct difference in susceptibility makes the optochin sensitivity test the definitive method for differentiating these two clinically important groups of streptococci.

questions.text: Which organism causes pneumonia and grows on BCYE (Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract) agar?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Legionella. 

Legionella pneumophila is a bacterium well-known for causing a severe form of pneumonia called Legionnaires' disease. A key characteristic of Legionella is its fastidious growth requirements; it specifically necessitates L-cysteine and iron for optimal growth. Buffered Charcoal Yeast Extract (BCYE) agar is a specialized culture medium precisely formulated to provide these essential nutrients (yeast extract as a nitrogen and vitamin source, L-cysteine, and ferric pyrophosphate as an iron source), along with activated charcoal to neutralize toxic substances, making it the selective medium of choice for isolating Legionella species.

questions.text: A farmer presents with ulcer, black eschar, and lymphadenopathy. Selective medium is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Bacillus anthracis Explanation: Cutaneous anthrax classically presents with painless ulcer with black eschar.

PLET. The patient's symptoms (farmer with ulcer, black eschar, and lymphadenopathy) are highly indicative of cutaneous anthrax, which is caused by Bacillus anthracis. PLET (Polymyxin-Lysozyme-EDTA-Thallous Acetate) agar is a specialized selective medium explicitly designed for the isolation and presumptive identification of Bacillus anthracis. Its specific components act to inhibit the growth of common contaminating bacteria while allowing Bacillus anthracis to grow, making it the appropriate choice for culturing this pathogen from clinical or environmental samples.

This mode of surveillance, where the public health authority primarily receives reports from healthcare providers without proactive case-finding efforts, is characteristic of passive surveillance.

questions.text: Which stage of the demographic cycle is associated with both high birth and high death rates?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

High stationary

The Demographic Transition Model describes how populations change over time through distinct stages. The High Stationary stage (Stage 1) is characterized by both very high birth rates and very high death rates. In this stage, population growth is minimal or stable because the high number of births is largely offset by a high number of deaths due to factors like disease, famine, and lack of sanitation. This equilibrium of high birth and death rates is a defining feature of the earliest stage of demographic transition.

This strategy of identifying a condition in its nascent or early stage to enable early intervention directly aligns with the goal of secondary prevention.

questions.text: Crude Birth Rate (CBR) is defined as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Number of live births per 1000 total population per year

Number of live births per 1000 total population per year. The Crude Birth Rate (CBR) is a fundamental demographic indicator that provides a simple measure of fertility within a population. It is calculated by dividing the total number of live births in a given year by the total mid-year population of that geographical area, and then multiplying the result by 1,000. This definition reflects its "crude" nature, as it considers the entire population without accounting for age, sex, or reproductive status, distinguishing it from more refined fertility rates.

questions.text: Which of the following toxins inhibits protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of EF-2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Diphtheria toxin. 

Diphtheria toxin, produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae, is a highly potent bacterial exotoxin notorious for its mechanism of action. It specifically inhibits protein synthesis in eukaryotic cells by catalyzing the ADP-ribosylation of Elongation Factor 2 (EF-2). This modification renders EF-2 inactive, preventing its crucial role in the translocation step of protein elongation on the ribosome, thereby leading to the complete cessation of protein synthesis and ultimately cell death.

Among the various patterns, the Rim pattern (or peripheral pattern), characterized by bright staining of the nuclear periphery, is considered the most specific immunofluorescence pattern for Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE). This pattern is strongly correlated with the presence of anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) antibodies, which are highly specific diagnostic markers for SLE.

questions.text: Which is false for the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Retinitis pigmentosa PRP is not needed here

Needs pan retinal photocoagulation. The image displays classic funduscopic findings of Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP), characterized by optic disc pallor, attenuated retinal vessels, and bone-spicule-shaped pigmentary deposits in the periphery. Retinitis Pigmentosa is a group of inherited degenerative diseases primarily affecting the photoreceptors (rods and cones), for which there is currently no cure, although some emerging gene therapies target specific genetic defects. Panretinal photocoagulation (PRP), a laser treatment to ablate peripheral retinal tissue, is indicated for conditions like proliferative diabetic retinopathy to prevent neovascularization, but it is not a treatment modality for Retinitis Pigmentosa. Therefore, the statement that it needs panretinal photocoagulation is false.

questions.text: ABG: pH 7.20, HCO3- = 6, pCO2 = 13, Na+= 136, Cl- = 110. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

• pH: 7.20 → acidemia

• HCO3

-: 6 mEq/L → very low (points to metabolic acidosis)

• pCO2: 13 mmHg → low (respiratory compensation)

• Na+: 136 mEq/L

• Cl-: 110 mEq/L

Clearly, this is metabolic acidosis because of low pH and low HCO3-.

AG = Na+ − (Cl- + HCO3 -)

AG = 136 − (110 + 6) = 136 − 116 = 20

Normal AG = ~12 (range 8–12) → so this is high AG metabolic acidosis.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male sustains a penetrating knife injury to the back.

Examination reveals: 

• Flaccid paralysis and areflexia at the L1 level 

• Ipsilateral spastic weakness and loss of vibration/proprioception below L1 

• Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning at L3 dermatome 

• Preserved bowel and bladder function 

What is the most precise localization of the spinal cord lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Right hemisection of spinal cord at L1

The patient's neurological findings, including ipsilateral flaccid paralysis and areflexia at the L1 level, ipsilateral spastic weakness and loss of vibration/proprioception below L1, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below L1, precisely describe Brown-Séquard syndrome. This syndrome is caused by a hemisection (damage to one half) of the spinal cord. Given the injury location is explicitly stated as the L1 level, the most precise localization of the lesion is a hemisection of the spinal cord at L1. The distinction between a right or left hemisection cannot be made without further information specifying the side of the ipsilateral symptoms (e.g., "right-sided weakness"). However, since options B and C both state "Right hemisection of spinal cord at L1," the intended answer indicates a hemisection at that specific vertebral level.

questions.text: A Patient of acute MI developed complete heart block. What will be the clinical sign in JVP?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cannon a wave. In a patient with acute myocardial infarction (MI) who develops complete heart block, there is a complete dissociation between the contractions of the atria and the ventricles. This means the atria contract independently of the ventricles. Occasionally, the right atrium will contract simultaneously against a closed tricuspid valve (which is closed because the right ventricle is in systole). This forceful contraction against a closed valve causes a very large and prominent pulse wave to be transmitted back into the jugular veins, which is known as a "cannon a wave" in the Jugular Venous Pulse (JVP). This specific finding is a classic clinical sign of atrioventricular dissociation, as seen in complete heart block.

questions.text: A 25 year old female came with chief complaints of vaginal discharge with lower abdominal pain and tenderness. Which color kit you will prescribe to her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Yellow color

The patient's presentation of vaginal discharge accompanied by lower abdominal pain and tenderness is clinically indicative of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID). In many public health programs, particularly in resource-limited settings, syndromic management of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) utilizes color-coded pre-packed drug kits to facilitate appropriate and prompt treatment. According to common international and national guidelines for syndromic management, the yellow kit is specifically designated for the treatment of vaginal discharge and/or lower abdominal pain, which covers conditions like PID, cervicitis, and vaginitis, providing broad-spectrum antibiotic coverage against likely causative pathogens.

choices.text: Proceed with IV alteplase at 0.9 mg/kg after informed consent
Defer thrombolysis due to low platelet count
Repeat CT after 1 hour to rule out early infarct signs

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents with acute left-sided hemiplegia and aphasia that started 3 hours ago. BP is 170/95 mmHg. Non-contrast CT brain shows no hemorrhage. Labs: Platelet count 90,000/mm³, INR 1.2, serum glucose 130 mg/dL, and creatinine 1.1 mg/dL. He has no prior stroke or surgery. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Defer thrombolysis due to low platelet count. The patient presents with acute ischemic stroke symptoms (left-sided hemiplegia and aphasia) within the 4.5-hour thrombolysis window, and the non-contrast CT brain shows no hemorrhage. However, a crucial lab finding is the platelet count of 90,000/mm³. A platelet count below 100,000/mm³ is a major contraindication for intravenous thrombolysis with alteplase due to a significantly increased risk of hemorrhagic complications. Therefore, despite meeting the time and imaging criteria, thrombolysis must be deferred because of the patient's low platelet count.

questions.text: A young male has persistent hemoptysis, digital clubbing, and copious foul-smelling sputum. CT chest shown. What is the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Bronchiectasis. 

The patient's clinical presentation of persistent hemoptysis, digital clubbing (a sign of chronic lung disease), and copious foul-smelling sputum (suggesting chronic infection in airways) is highly characteristic of bronchiectasis. The provided CT chest image further confirms this diagnosis by showing classic radiographic signs: abnormally dilated bronchi with thickened walls, visible as "tram-track" opacities when viewed longitudinally (long arrow) and "signet-ring" signs (short arrow) when viewed in cross-section. These irreversible bronchial dilatations and associated inflammation are the hallmarks of bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with Ischemic cardiomyopathy in Chronic HF presents complaining of nausea and vomiting. Examination reveals Grade 2 pedal edema and elevated JVP. Laboratory values include serum Na of 125 mmol/L, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 25 mg/dL, creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL, urine Na of 40 with FeNa of 5%. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Acute Tubular necrosis (ATN)

The case of chronic heart failure indicates chronic hypoperfusion leading to acute tubular necrosis.

Fractional excretion of sodium [FENa(%)] is used in determining the cause of renal failure. FENa(%) = (urine sodium/serum sodium)/(urine creatinine/serum creatinine) × 100. The following table illustrates the laboratory findings in the different types of renal failure. failure.

questions.text: Patient present with lesions as shown in the image, later patient also developed arthritis. What is the treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Methotrexate

The image depicts skin lesions characteristic of Psoriasis, and the patient's subsequent development of arthritis points to a diagnosis of Psoriatic Arthritis. Methotrexate is a widely recognized and effective systemic disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) frequently used as a first-line treatment for moderate to severe psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis. It works by suppressing the immune system and reducing inflammation, thereby helping to control both the skin symptoms and the joint inflammation associated with the condition.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with fluctuating ptosis and dysphagia has normal reflexes and pupil size. Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. Which structure is primarily affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors. The patient's presentation of fluctuating ptosis and dysphagia, which are classic signs of muscle weakness that worsens with activity, along with a decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation, is highly characteristic of Myasthenia Gravis. In Myasthenia Gravis, the immune system mistakenly produces antibodies that target and destroy or block the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction. This reduction in functional receptors impairs the transmission of nerve signals to the muscle, leading to the observed muscle weakness. The normal reflexes and pupil size help differentiate it from other neuromuscular junction disorders.

choices.text: Continue insulin at the same rate and monitor potassium
Stop insulin immediately and administer dextrose
Continue insulin and give IV potassium supplementation
Administer sodium bicarbonate to correct acidosis

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes presents with vomiting, Kussmaul respiration, and confusion. 

Labs reveal: 

• Blood glucose: 510 mg/dL 

• Arterial pH: 7.05 

• HCO₃⁻: 9 mEq/L 

• Serum potassium: 5.2 mEq/L

She is started on IV fluids and insulin infusion. After 2 hours, her serum potassium drops to 3.2 mEq/L. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Continue insulin and give IV potassium supplementation. 

The patient has Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) and is receiving appropriate initial treatment with IV fluids and insulin. A critical complication during DKA treatment is the rapid shift of potassium from the extracellular to the intracellular space due to insulin's action, leading to a drop in serum potassium. The patient's potassium level of 3.2 mEq/L indicates hypokalemia. To prevent dangerous cardiac arrhythmias and ensure the continued resolution of DKA, it is essential to continue the insulin infusion (which is correcting the underlying metabolic derangements) while simultaneously providing intravenous potassium supplementation to replete the decreasing serum levels.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of alcoholic liver disease presents with ascites. Diagnostic ascitic fluid analysis done. Which of the following ascitic fluid results is most likely to suggest that ascites is due to cirrhosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ascitic fluid in uncomplicated cirrhosis of the liver shows a specific gravity 1.1 g/dL. In spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, the fluid may be cloudy and the number of white cells (neutrophils) increased. In uncomplicated ascites, the difference between plasma albumin and ascitic fluid albumin is >1.1 g/dL.

questions.text: An individual tests positive for HBsAg, negative for Anti-HBs, and positive for Anti-HBc IgG. What is the most likely interpretation of these results?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Interpretation of the given profile: 

HBsAg: Positive ? Patient has active HBV infection Anti-HBs: Negative ? Patient has not cleared the virus; no immunity Anti-HBc IgG: Positive ? Indicates a past or ongoing natural infection (not vaccinated)

questions.text: A patient presented with hypopigmented macules over back and upper trunk. On KOH mount spaghetti and meat ball appearance was seen. What can be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Malassezia furfur

The patient's presentation of hypopigmented macules predominantly on the back and upper trunk, combined with the characteristic "spaghetti and meatball appearance" observed on a KOH mount, are classic diagnostic features of Tinea versicolor (also known as Pityriasis versicolor). This common superficial fungal infection is caused by the lipophilic yeast, Malassezia furfur (or other Malassezia species like Malassezia globosa), which produces compounds that interfere with melanin production, leading to the patchy hypopigmentation. The "spaghetti and meatball" appearance microscopically represents the mixture of short hyphae and budding yeast forms of this fungus.

questions.text: A patient of SLE is on maintenance therapy with Hydroxychloroquine. Following test/s are indicated to monitor the ADR of the treatment
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Fundoscopy and ECG. Hydroxychloroquine, commonly used in the long-term management of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE), is associated with two main serious adverse drug reactions that require regular monitoring. The most critical is retinal toxicity (maculopathy), which necessitates regular ophthalmologic examinations including fundoscopy and often more advanced tests like OCT. Additionally, Hydroxychloroquine can cause cardiotoxicity, including cardiomyopathy and conduction abnormalities, which warrants periodic ECG monitoring. Therefore, fundoscopy and ECG are the key tests indicated to monitor for these significant adverse effects.

questions.text: The following are findings in a case of Distal Renal tubular acidosis EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Hypocalciuria Explanation: Distal RTA often leads to recurrent kidney stones due to the paracellular defect of Calcium reabsorption leading to hypercalciuria. Majority cases also have hypocitraturia increasing risk of precipitation of calcium in urine leading to Nephrocalcinosis. Inability to reabsorb potassium and magnesium leads to deficiency in blood

questions.text: This figure is suggestive of which murmur
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mitral valve prolapse. 

The figure illustrates a murmur that becomes more prominent or longer with sudden standing and less prominent or shorter with sudden squatting. This pattern is characteristic of Mitral Valve Prolapse (MVP). When a person stands suddenly, the venous return to the heart decreases, leading to a smaller left ventricular (LV) volume. A smaller LV volume allows the mitral valve leaflets to prolapse earlier in systole, causing the associated murmur to start earlier and become longer and often louder. Conversely, when a person squats suddenly, venous return and LV volume increase, which delays the prolapse and causes the murmur to be shorter and often softer. This direct inverse relationship between LV volume and the timing/prominence of the MVP murmur perfectly matches the visual representation.

choices.text: A mild exophthalmos may be associated A. with thyrotoxicosis and an extreme exophthalmos in any state of thyroid activity
The retraction of the lid is due to contraction of Levator muscle
Werner classification reflects the severity of the ophthalmopathy
Systemic Steroids is mainstay of management

questions.text: Which is false for thyroid eye disease
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

The retraction of the lid is due to contraction of Levator muscle. 

This statement is false for thyroid eye disease. While the levator palpebrae superioris muscle elevates the eyelid, the characteristic eyelid retraction seen in thyroid eye disease is primarily caused by sympathetic overstimulation of Müller's muscle (superior tarsal muscle). Müller's muscle is a small smooth muscle that contributes to eyelid elevation, and its hypertonicity due to sympathetic activity is the main reason for the widening of the palpebral fissure (lid retraction) in this condition, rather than direct contraction of the levator muscle as the sole or primary cause of the retraction.

questions.text: All are seen in this condition except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Munro microabscess/kogoj pustules

Munro microabscess/kogoj pustules. The image displays clinical features highly suggestive of Lichen Planus, characterized by small, reddish-purple, polygonal, pruritic, and often shiny papules, potentially with Wickham striae. While Wickham striae, saw-tooth acanthosis (histologically), and Civatte bodies (apoptotic keratinocytes) are all characteristic features of Lichen Planus, Munro microabscesses and Kogoj pustules are histological hallmarks of Psoriasis, not Lichen Planus. Therefore, these specific findings are not seen in the condition depicted.

questions.text: The amplitude of accommodation gradually diminishes throughout life causing near point to go away from eye is called
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

The amplitude of accommodation gradually diminishes throughout life , causing Presbyopia

Presbyopia. Presbyopia is the age-related physiological loss of the eye's ability to focus on nearby objects. This condition directly results from the gradual stiffening and loss of elasticity of the crystalline lens, combined with a decrease in the effectiveness of the ciliary muscle's action. Consequently, the eye's amplitude of accommodation (its ability to change focus) progressively diminishes throughout life, causing the near point (the closest distance at which an object can be seen clearly) to recede. This makes tasks like reading or working at close distances increasingly difficult, perfectly matching the description provided.

choices.text: Remove Central Line and Chest X-ray

questions.text: A patient develops sudden chest pain and breathlessness after central line insertion with Hypotension. Trachea is shifted to the opposite side. Best management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Immediate needle decompression. The patient's symptoms—sudden chest pain and breathlessness, combined with hypotension and, most critically, tracheal shift to the opposite side after central line insertion—are the classic triad of signs for a tension pneumothorax. This is a life-threatening medical emergency where air accumulates in the pleural space and cannot escape, compressing the lung and shifting mediastinal structures, severely impairing cardiac output. Immediate needle decompression is the definitive and life-saving intervention required to relieve the dangerously high intrathoracic pressure.

questions.text: A secondary open-angle glaucoma developed if the lens has been damaged or if lens proteins from a hypermature senile cataract escape into the aqueous is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Phacolytic glaucoma. 

This condition specifically describes a form of secondary open-angle glaucoma that develops when the lens proteins, released from a hypermature cataract due to a compromised lens capsule, escape into the anterior chamber of the eye. These leaked, high-molecular-weight lens proteins, along with macrophages that attempt to phagocytose them, subsequently accumulate and clog the trabecular meshwork. This obstruction impedes the normal outflow of aqueous humor, leading to an increase in intraocular pressure, thereby causing an open-angle glaucoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presents with hemoptysis and weight loss. Bronchoscopy reveals a central mass obstructing the right main bronchus. Blood investigations shows Anemia and Hypercalcemia . CXR is given . Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Squamous cell carcinoma. The patient's history of being a chronic smoker, the bronchoscopy finding of a centrally obstructing mass in the right main bronchus, and the symptom of hemoptysis are all highly characteristic features of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung. Most crucially, the presence of hypercalcemia in the blood investigations strongly supports this diagnosis, as squamous cell carcinoma is the lung cancer type most frequently associated with paraneoplastic hypercalcemia due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related protein (PTHrP). Furthermore, squamous cell carcinomas commonly arise centrally and have a tendency to cavitate, which might be suggested by the appearance of the mass on the chest X-ray.

choices.text: Compound hypermetropic astigmatism, with the rule
Compound myopic astigmatism, with the rule
Simple myopic astigmatism, against the rule
Compound myopic astigmatism, against the rule

questions.text: A child came to OPD and was prescribed-2D sphere with -1D cylinder @180. What is the refractive error of that eye of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The vertical power will be -3D Horizontal power will be -2D Vertical more steeper

Compound myopic astigmatism, with the rule. The given prescription is -2D sphere with -1D cylinder @180. To determine the refractive error, we calculate the power in the two principal meridians. The horizontal meridian (180 degrees) has only the spherical power, which is -2D. The vertical meridian (90 degrees) has the sum of the spherical and cylindrical power, resulting in -2D + (-1D) = -3D. Since both principal meridians are myopic (negative power) and have different powers, it is a Compound Myopic Astigmatism. Furthermore, the vertical meridian (-3D) has more minus power than the horizontal meridian (-2D), indicating that the vertical meridian is steeper. This pattern, where the vertical meridian is the steepest, defines With-the-rule astigmatism.

questions.text: A known asthmatic presents with silent chest, altered sensorium, and PaCO2 of 75 mmHg. Best next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Intubate and initiate mechanical ventilation. The patient's presentation with a "silent chest" (indicating severely reduced air movement), altered sensorium (suggesting hypercapnic encephalopathy), and a critically elevated PaCO2 of 75 mmHg (severe respiratory acidosis and hypercapnia) are all hallmark signs of impending or actual respiratory arrest in severe asthma. In this life-threatening situation, immediate intubation and initiation of mechanical ventilation are required to secure the airway, ensure adequate oxygenation, facilitate CO2 removal, and provide ventilatory support to fatigued respiratory muscles, as other less invasive measures are unlikely to be effective enough or quick enough to prevent respiratory collapse.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old male presents with chronic fatigue, salt craving, postural dizziness, and progressive skin darkening over knuckles and oral mucosa. 

His labs reveal: 

• Serum Na⁺: 124 mEq/L 

• Serum K⁺: 5.8 mEq/L 

• Morning cortisol: 4 μg/dL (low) 

• Plasma ACTH: 950 pg/mL (↑↑) 

• ACTH stimulation test: cortisol rises to 6 μg/dL after 60 min 

Which of the following is the most accurate interpretation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Consistent with primary adrenal insufficiency. The patient's clinical presentation of chronic fatigue, salt craving, postural dizziness, and particularly the progressive skin darkening (hyperpigmentation) are classic symptoms of primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison's disease). The laboratory findings strongly confirm this: low morning cortisol and a failed ACTH stimulation test indicate adrenal gland failure, while the very high plasma ACTH level (950 pg/mL) confirms that the pituitary is overworking to stimulate non-responsive adrenal glands. Additionally, hyponatremia and hyperkalemia are common electrolyte derangements seen in primary adrenal insufficiency due to mineralocorticoid deficiency.

questions.text: A 65 yr old male presented with diminuition of vision in right eye with redness and pain. On examination, the IOP was 50 mmHg right eye. The right eye had shallow anterior chamber with some cells. The lens was totally white. What could be the possibility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Phacomorphic glaucoma. 

This diagnosis perfectly explains the patient's acute presentation. Phacomorphic glaucoma occurs when a cataractous lens, particularly a hypermature or intumescent (swollen) one like the "totally white lens" described, increases significantly in size. This swelling causes the lens to push the iris forward, leading to a shallow anterior chamber and subsequent pupillary block. The pupillary block then obstructs the outflow of aqueous humor, resulting in a sudden and severe elevation of intraocular pressure (IOP 50 mmHg), causing acute pain, redness, and rapid diminution of vision.

choices.text: Wernicke pupil is observed in lesion causing this defect

questions.text: Which is false for following visual field charting
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Left homonymous hemianopia Seen in right optic tract lesion

Bitemporal hemianopia. The visual field chart clearly displays a right homonymous hemianopia, which means there is a loss of vision in the entire right half of the visual field for both the left and right eyes. In contrast, bitemporal hemianopia specifically refers to the loss of vision in the temporal (outer) halves of both visual fields, a pattern typically caused by a lesion at the optic chiasm. Since the depicted visual field defect is homonymous and not bitemporal, the statement classifying it as bitemporal hemianopia is false.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is diagnosed with acromegaly due to a GH-secreting pituitary macroadenoma. MRI shows a large sellar mass with suprasellar extension. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Transsphenoidal surgical resection. The patient has acromegaly caused by a GH-secreting pituitary macroadenoma, and importantly, the MRI shows suprasellar extension. This extension indicates that the tumor is large and likely compressing adjacent vital structures, such as the optic chiasm, which can lead to vision loss. In such cases, surgical removal via the transsphenoidal approach is generally considered the most appropriate initial treatment. Its primary advantages are the potential for rapid reduction of GH/IGF-1 levels and, crucially, immediate decompression of the optic chiasm to preserve or improve vision, making it the preferred first-line intervention for symptomatic macroadenomas.

choices.text: The right lobe is divided into medial and lateral segments.
Right hepatectomy is removal of segment 4, 5, 6, 7, 8.
The left lobe is divided into anterior and posterior segments.

questions.text: Regarding segmental hepatic anatomy, which of the following is the most accurate statement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Surgical anatomy of the liver

Functionally the liver is divided into a right and left hemi-liver by the principal plane (Rex-Cantlie line). This is a plane passing through the medial edge of gallbladder bed towards the vena cava.

Couinaud in 1957 provided the definitive description of liver.

The right hemi-liver is divided into anterior and posterior sections by the right hepatic vein The left hemi-liver is divided into lateral and medial sections by the left hepatic vein.

Further portal inflow division results in each section in turn being subdivided into two segments.

The right portal pedicle is short (less than 1 cm in most) and the vein divides to supply the right anterior section, subdivided into segments V (inferior) and VIII (superior) by portal vein divisions and the right posterior section subdivided into segments VI (inferior) and VII (superior) by portal vein divisions.

The left portal pedicle gives of a caudate branch and thereafter the vein divides to supply a left lateral section (segment II) and a left medial section (Segment III and IV).

The caudate lobe is a distinct anatomical segment and is labeled segment I. It receives branches of the portal trinity from the right and left liver and drains independently into the vena cava.

As each segment of liver has its own supply from the portal trinity, independent of the other segments, these can therefore be resected independently of other segments.

choices.text: This child should be treated by diverticulectomy

questions.text: A 10 year old child presented with off and on Bleeding P/R. Tc 99 scan is given below. What is the ideal treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Tc scan is suggestive of Meckel’s diverticulum with ectopic tissue. It should be treated by Resection and anastomosis of ileum with Meckel’s.

Resection and anastomosis of ileum. While a simple diverticulectomy (removal of just the pouch) can be performed for uncomplicated Meckel's, for a symptomatic, bleeding Meckel's diverticulum (as indicated by the positive Tc-99m scan for ectopic gastric mucosa), a segmental ileal resection with primary anastomosis is often considered the ideal treatment. This approach ensures complete removal of the diverticulum along with any potentially acid-producing ectopic gastric mucosa that might extend into the adjacent ileal wall, thereby minimizing the risk of persistent or recurrent bleeding and other complications.

choices.text: Sugammadex – due to specific encapsulation of rocuronium

questions.text: A 45-year-old female undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy receives rocuronium for neuromuscular blockade. At the end of surgery, the anesthesiologist decides to reverse the block rapidly. Which of the following agents is most appropriate and why?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Sugammadex - due to specific encapsulation of rocuronium. The patient received rocuronium, a steroidal non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker. When rapid reversal of rocuronium's effects is desired, Sugammadex is the most appropriate agent. Sugammadex is a unique drug that works by encapsulating (forming a tight complex with) rocuronium molecules in the plasma. This effectively removes rocuronium from the neuromuscular junction, leading to a very rapid and complete reversal of the neuromuscular blockade, which is a significant advantage over traditional acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine for this specific type of neuromuscular blocker.

questions.text: A 30 year old male patient presented with complains of perianal opening with pus discharge. What is best investigation for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

MRI fistulogram. 

The patient's presentation of a perianal opening with pus discharge is characteristic of an anal fistula. The best investigation for this condition aims to precisely map the fistula tract(s), identify any internal openings, and delineate its relationship with the anal sphincter muscles. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging) offers superior soft tissue contrast resolution, making it the gold standard for accurately visualizing the complex anatomy of anal fistulas, detecting any extensions or associated abscesses, and guiding surgical planning to minimize recurrence and preserve continence.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female underwent MRM (Modified Radical Mastectomy). After few years, she developed lymphedema of the ipsilateral arm. Which of the following malignancy can develop in her arm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lymphangiosarcoma

Lymphangiosarcoma. The patient's history of Modified Radical Mastectomy (MRM) leading to chronic lymphedema of the ipsilateral arm is a classic predisposing factor for the development of lymphangiosarcoma. This is a rare, aggressive vascular malignancy that specifically arises from the lymphatic endothelial cells within the chronically swollen, lymphedematous limb. This well-recognized association is historically termed Stewart-Treves syndrome.

choices.text: Superficial head of Flexor Pollicis brevis

questions.text: All of the following muscles are supplied by the Lateral division of the Deep branch of the Median Nerve except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

2nd Lumbrical.

The question asks which muscle is not supplied by the lateral division of the deep branch of the median nerve. The deep branch of the median nerve typically splits into a lateral and a medial division. The lateral division supplies the thenar muscles (Opponens Pollicis, Abductor Pollicis Brevis, Superficial head of Flexor Pollicis Brevis) and the 1st Lumbrical. In contrast, the 2nd Lumbrical is supplied by the medial division of the deep branch of the median nerve. Therefore, the 2nd Lumbrical is the exception among the choices provided.
