questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Blind ending artery is suggestive of Anorchia

choices.text: A 34-year-old whose mother, maternal grandmother, and aunt all developed breast cancer
A 57-year-old man with no family history of breast cancer
A 58-year-old woman with an ER/PR positive tumor

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman undergoes mammography to investigate a mass discovered on breast exam in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. She has a variety of questions, including further workup and possible treatment options. Which of the following patients with breast cancer would be the best candidate for hormonal therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Principles of Surgical Physiology/Breast Disease/Hormone Therapy for Breast Cancer. Hormone therapy in breast cancer works for those tumors with estrogen receptor/progesterone receptor (ER/PR)-positive cells.

Patients with these tumor types have better outcomes in general, and for postmenopausal women, hormone therapy is as effective as chemotherapy in treating ER/PR-positive breast cancer. Hormone therapy works by blocking the growth that natural hormones would cause in the cancer cells either
by blocking estrogen receptors (tamoxifen and raloxifene) or by inhibiting excess estrogen synthesis (aromatase inhibitors such as anastrozole).

A. Heritable breast cancers are not necessarily good candidates for hormone therapy. Response to hormone therapy can be predicted only by the presence or absence or hormone receptors on tumor cells.

B. Males with breast cancer are not necessarily good candidates for hormone therapy. Response to hormone therapy can be predicted only by the presence or absence or hormone receptors on tumor cells.

D. Patients with the BRCA-1/2 mutation are not necessarily good candidates for hormone therapy. Response to hormone therapy can be predicted only by the presence or absence or hormone receptors on tumor cells.

choices.text: To prevent alveolar collapse and improve oxygenation

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with ARDS is on mechanical ventilation. The intensivist increases PEEP from 5 to 10 cm H2O. What is the primary physiological rationale for increasing PEEP in this setting?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Explanation: PEEP helps keep alveoli open at end expiration, improving gas exchange and oxygenation, especially in conditions like ARDS where alveoli are prone to collapse.

To prevent alveolar collapse and improve oxygenation. In Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS), the lungs suffer from widespread inflammation and fluid accumulation, leading to the collapse of numerous tiny air sacs (alveoli). This collapse (atelectasis) severely impairs the ability of the lungs to oxygenate the blood. Positive End-Expiratory Pressure (PEEP) works by maintaining a positive pressure in the airways at the end of exhalation, which physically holds these collapsed alveoli open. By recruiting more functional alveoli, PEEP effectively increases the surface area available for gas exchange, thereby significantly improving the patient's oxygen levels and overall oxygenation.

choices.text: Whole body rewarming and tissue salvage
Vigorous rubbing to regain circulation , and the draining of hemorrhagic blisters
Gentle rewarming, if the patient is able to maintain warmth, and ibuprofen
Plasma volume restoration and thrombolytic treatment

questions.text:
A patient presented to hospital after prolonged exposure in severe cold condition

Frostbitten tissues should be immediately treated by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Frostbitten tissue should be protected from friction or trauma but should not be thawed until there is confidence in the ability to maintain warmth. Gentle rewarming in a water bath (30° to 43° C) is recommended. Ibuprofen should be started in the field at a dose of 12 mg/kg (divided twice daily) to
inhibit harmful prostaglandins.

choices.text: Cross-sectional imaging (CT or magnetic resonance imaging [MRI])

questions.text: What imaging modality is most often used to characterize and diagnose GIST?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

• 2- 3% of gastric cancer

• GIST arises from intretstitial cell of Cajal, autonomic nerve–related GI pacemaker cells (mesenchymal components) from Muscle layers.

• Most common sites: Stomach (50-60%)> Small Intestine, ileum (25%) > Rectum/ Esophagus.

• Most are positive for CD117 (>90%), CD 34 (>70%), BCL 2.

• 5% associated with plate derived growth factor alpha- 5% (PDGF α has good prognosis)

• Other tumor markers are DOG1 and protein kinase C theta.

• Two types: Spindle cell (70% most common), epitheloid (30%) and rarely pleomorphic.

• Age of presentation after 5th decade, usually around 60 years.

• Main presenting symptom: Bleeding (75%) > Pain and dyspepsia. Mass in 60%

• Malignant potential is decided by:

o 1: Size > 5 cm

o 2: metastasis: Vascular or peritoneal (Lymphatic involvement is very rare- 5%-10%)

o 3: Mitotic Index: > 5 / 50 HPF

o 4: Cellular atypia, necrosis, or local invasion.

o 5: c-kit mutations occur predominantly in malignant GISTs and are an unfavorable prognostic marker. Most c-kit mutations occur in exon 11 and result in activation of c-kit

Investigation:

CECT: for primary tumour

PET: For secondary.

EUS: For biopsy (GIST found in layer 4 > 2)

Treatment: Surgical resection (segmental with 1 cm margin)

Node involvement is very rare (so lymphadenectomy is not usually required).

• Imatinib mesylate (selective inhibitor of type 3 tyrosine kinase KIT) is best adjuvant therapy. Used in CD117 positive unrespectable tumour or metastatic GIST.

• PET is best investigation to assess response of Imatinib

• Sunitinib is used in Imatinib resistance cases.

• This tumor is radio resistant

• Tumour size is predominant factor for survival.

• Most common site of disease failure in Liver

questions.text: A 31-year-old road traffic accident victim is being token up for emergency laparotomy for haemoperitoneum and suspected multiorgan trauma. Which one of the following will be an indication for performing damage control surgery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Coagupathy

Damage Control Surgery (DCS) is a critical strategy employed for severely injured trauma patients in a state of physiological decompensation. A key indication for initiating DCS is the presence of the "lethal triad" which includes acidosis, hypothermia, and coagulopathy. Coagulopathy, or impaired blood clotting, is particularly crucial because it directly contributes to uncontrolled hemorrhage, making definitive surgical repair impossible and perpetuating the patient's critical condition. By performing an abbreviated surgery to control immediate bleeding and then focusing on correcting the coagulopathy (along with acidosis and hypothermia) in the ICU, DCS aims to break this vicious cycle and improve survival.

questions.text: Hawkins classification used in which fracture:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Talus.

The Hawkins classification system is a widely recognized and utilized classification system in orthopedics specifically for fractures of the talus neck. This classification categorizes talus neck fractures based on the degree of displacement, which is critical because it directly correlates with the risk of developing avascular necrosis (AVN) of the talus. Higher grades of displacement in the Hawkins classification indicate a greater disruption of the blood supply to the talus, leading to a higher likelihood of AVN, a significant complication that can impact long-term ankle function.

questions.text: A 35 year male presented with haematuria, Hypertension and mild abdominal pain. CECT is given below. This condition is associated with which Chromosomes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

ADPK is associated with Chromosome 16 and 4 Discuss all congenital anomalies

The image clearly shows massively enlarged kidneys extensively filled with cysts, which is the hallmark of Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD). The patient's symptoms (hematuria, hypertension, mild abdominal pain) are also highly consistent with ADPKD.

ADPKD is a well-characterized genetic disorder. Its primary causes are mutations in:

The PKD1 gene, located on Chromosome 16. This gene accounts for the vast majority (around 85%) of ADPKD cases.

The PKD2 gene, located on Chromosome 4. This gene accounts for a smaller proportion (around 15%) of ADPKD cases, typically leading to a milder phenotype.

Therefore, the condition depicted (ADPKD) is definitively associated with Chromosome 16 and Chromosome 4 (Option A).

There is no established direct genetic association of widespread polycystic kidney disease, as shown in the image, with Chromosome 17 and Chromosome 13. While isolated renal cysts or less severe cystic kidney diseases can rarely be associated with other genetic defects (e.g., HNF1B on Chromosome 17 in RCAD syndrome), the image's classic presentation is of ADPKD.

questions.text: All of the following are included in Mirel’s criteria except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Side of lesion.

Mirel's criteria are a widely used scoring system to predict the risk of pathological fractures in bones affected by metastatic cancer. The criteria take into account four specific parameters: the site of the lesion (e.g., upper limb, lower limb), the size of the lesion (percentage of cortical involvement), the type of lesion (lytic, blastic, or mixed), and the level of pain experienced by the patient. The specific side of the body (left or right) where the lesion is located is not a factor considered or scored within Mirel's criteria as it does not influence the biomechanical stability or fracture risk.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed as a case of stage T2a prostate cancer. He was treated by the treatment modality shown in the image. Which radio-isotope is not used for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Yttrium-90 (Y-90). 

The image displays tiny radioactive "seeds" implanted in the prostate, which is a form of internal radiation therapy called brachytherapy for prostate cancer. While Iodine-125 (I-125), Iridium-192 (Ir-192), and Palladium-103 (Pd-103) are all well-established radioisotopes used in various forms of prostate brachytherapy (both permanent seed and temporary high-dose-rate implants), Yttrium-90 is not used for this purpose. Yttrium-90 is primarily used in selective internal radiation therapy (SIRT) for treating liver tumors, where it is delivered via microspheres into the hepatic artery.

questions.text:
A patient underwent surgery for GIST stomach. Excision with 1 cm margin was done. In follow up,

Which is the best investigation to assess the recurrence of GIST
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

PET is considered better for follow up in GIST

Positron emission tomography (PET) scan. While CT scans are widely used for GIST surveillance, PET scans, particularly FDG-PET/CT, are considered superior for detecting active tumor recurrence. GISTs are highly metabolically active and show intense uptake of FDG, allowing PET to identify viable tumor cells even when lesions are small or anatomically subtle on conventional imaging. This functional imaging capability makes PET highly sensitive for detecting metabolically active recurrent disease, often earlier than changes in size visible on CT or MRI, thus making it the "best" investigation for assessing recurrence.

Late complications are – Retrograde ejaculation (commonest 75%- MCQ), Bladder neck contracture (Mainly seen in small prostate <20 gms, where TUIP is better than TURP),
impotence, incontinence.

questions.text:
A 3 week old male child is having recurrent non bilious vomiting after feeding. His X ray is given below.

Which of the following is most consistent finding with condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Single bubble sign is suggestive of CHPS. Electrolyte finding in CHPS is Hypochloremic, Hypokalemic metabolism alkalosis.

Na 139 Cl 85 K 3.2 HCO3 36. The clinical presentation of a 3-week-old male with recurrent non-bilious vomiting and the X-ray showing a "double bubble" sign (dilated stomach and duodenum) are classic for a high intestinal obstruction, most commonly duodenal atresia/stenosis or pyloric stenosis. Persistent vomiting, especially non-bilious (indicating loss of gastric contents), leads to a characteristic metabolic derangement: hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis. This occurs due to the loss of gastric acid (HCl) and subsequent compensatory mechanisms in the kidneys. Option D accurately reflects this metabolic imbalance with normal sodium, low chloride (85), low potassium (3.2), and elevated bicarbonate (36).

questions.text:
A 35 year old man is involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was thrown against the steering column. He sustains a blunt trauma injury to his left upper abdomen. On arrival at the emergency department, he complains of abdominal pain, but is hemodynamically stable. CT scan a spleenic tear and a retained smal intraabdominal hematoma, the tear extendes through the splenic capsule, but not to the hilum.

Which of the following treatment options is least likely to be indicated in this case at this time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Exploratory laprotomy

Exploratory laparotomy. The patient presents with a blunt splenic injury and a small contained hematoma, but critically, is described as hemodynamically stable. For hemodynamically stable patients with isolated blunt splenic trauma, the standard of care is non-operative management (NOM). This involves close monitoring (e.g., in ICU), serial imaging (e.g., serial CT scans), and preparing for potential blood transfusions (cross-match). Exploratory laparotomy, which is invasive surgery, is typically reserved only for patients who are hemodynamically unstable, have evidence of ongoing massive bleeding, or fail non-operative management. Therefore, performing an immediate exploratory laparotomy is the least likely indicated treatment at this time.

choices.text: Blood is still flowing the pulmonary artery to the aorta as in the fetal circulation
Chest wall and ribs are too complaint
There is ventilation perfusion mismatch from surfactant deficiency

questions.text: A 32 years gestation,33 weeks gestation female infant delivered by caesarean section, birth weight 1.9 kg, no resuscitation is required.There is distress with respiratory rate of 70 breaths/min, retractions present. Respiratory support is required with CPAP (Continuous positive airway pressure) and 45% oxygen is required. Most likely cause of oxygen therapy and respiratory support is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

There is ventilation perfusion mismatch from surfactant deficiency. 

The patient is a 33-week gestation premature infant, a demographic highly susceptible to Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS). RDS in preterm infants is primarily caused by an insufficient amount or function of pulmonary surfactant, which is vital for preventing the collapse of alveoli. Without adequate surfactant, widespread alveolar collapse (atelectasis) occurs, leading to large areas of the lung being perfused with blood but not properly ventilated. This creates a significant ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, resulting in severe hypoxemia and the characteristic signs of respiratory distress (tachypnea, retractions) requiring oxygen therapy and positive pressure support like CPAP to keep the alveoli open and improve gas exchange.

choices.text: Systemic absorption due to tourniquet failure
Delayed onset of action of lignocaine

questions.text: A 30-year-old male undergoes a forearm tendon repair under IVRA using lignocaine. Ten minutes after drug administration, he complains of dizziness and perioral numbness. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

 Systemic absorption due to tourniquet failure. Intravenous Regional Anesthesia (IVRA) relies on a tourniquet to isolate the limb and keep the local anesthetic, such as lignocaine, confined to that area. If this tourniquet fails or is released prematurely, the lignocaine can rapidly enter the patient's systemic circulation. Dizziness and perioral numbness are classic early signs of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), indicating that the lignocaine has reached toxic levels in the bloodstream and is affecting the central nervous system. Therefore, the most likely cause of these symptoms in this scenario is the unintended systemic absorption of lignocaine due to a compromised tourniquet.

questions.text: False statement about testicular tumour is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Extragonadal germ cell tumor has better prognosis and twice the survival as compared to germ cell tumour.

Extragonadal germ cell tumor has better prognosis and twice the survival as compared to germ cell tumour. This statement is false. Extragonadal germ cell tumors (EGGCTs), which originate outside the testes (commonly in the mediastinum or retroperitoneum), generally have a worse prognosis and lower survival rates compared to primary testicular germ cell tumors. Testicular germ cell tumors, especially in localized stages, have excellent cure rates and a very good prognosis. Therefore, the claim that extragonadal forms have a better prognosis and twice the survival is incorrect.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman fell from the roof of her house. Paramedics on arrival report that she is opening her eyes when commanded, response to painful stimuli by withdrawing her arms and speaks with inappropriate words. Her vital signs are stable. What is her current GCS
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

10

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is calculated by summing scores from three categories: Eye Opening (E), Verbal Response (V), and Motor Response (M). For Eye Opening, "opening her eyes when commanded" scores 3 (E3 - to speech). For Motor Response, "response to painful stimuli by withdrawing her arms" scores 4 (M4 - withdrawal from pain). For Verbal Response, "speaks with inappropriate words" scores 3 (V3 - inappropriate words). Summing these scores: GCS = E3 + M4 + V3 = 10.

questions.text: Examination of a term child at birth shows cleft lip & palate, small area of scalp where there is no skin and six toes on both feet. He has a loud systolic murmur. This is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Patau syndrome

The constellation of severe congenital anomalies presented, including a cleft lip and palate, a highly characteristic small area of absent skin on the scalp (cutis aplasia), six toes on both feet (polydactyly), and a loud systolic murmur indicating a congenital heart defect, collectively points to Patau syndrome, or Trisomy 13. These specific features are commonly observed in infants affected by Trisomy 13, making it the most fitting diagnosis among the given chromosomal abnormalities.

questions.text: A mother is found to have glycosuria at 32 weeks gestation. Her glucose tolerance test and fasting glucose is abnormal. There is increased risk of following in newborn baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Respiratory distress syndrome

Respiratory distress syndrome. A mother with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) at 32 weeks gestation indicates uncontrolled hyperglycemia during pregnancy. This elevated maternal glucose can lead to fetal hyperinsulinemia, where the fetal pancreas produces excess insulin in response to the high glucose levels. This hyperinsulinemia in the fetus is known to delay lung maturation, specifically by interfering with the production and release of pulmonary surfactant. Surfactant is essential for preventing alveolar collapse in the newborn's lungs. Consequently, infants born to mothers with uncontrolled GDM have a significantly increased risk of developing Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS), even if born at term.

questions.text: A couple has two children affected with tuberous sclerosis. On detailed clinical and laboratory evaluation (including molecular studies) both parents are normal. Which one of the following explains the two affected children in this family?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Germline mosaicism

Tuberous Sclerosis is an autosomal dominant disorder, meaning typically only one copy of a mutated gene (either TSC1 or TSC2) is sufficient to cause the disease. In this scenario, with two affected children but both parents appearing clinically and genetically normal, germline mosaicism is the most fitting explanation. Germline mosaicism occurs when a mutation is present in a portion of a parent's germ cells (sperm or egg) but is absent from their somatic cells. This means the parent themselves does not express the disease and their routine genetic testing (usually on blood samples, which are somatic cells) would appear normal. However, they can still pass the mutation to multiple offspring, explaining how two children in the same family could be affected by an autosomal dominant condition even with outwardly unaffected and genetically "normal" parents.

choices.text: Leave the patient supine and monitor
Turn the patient into the recovery (lateral) position

questions.text:
A 30-year-old unconscious patient with normal breathing and a palpable pulse is being managed
in a public park. While waiting for EMS, which of the following is the correct next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Turn the patient into the recovery (lateral) position. For an unconscious patient who is still breathing normally and has a palpable pulse, the most immediate and crucial concern is maintaining a clear airway and preventing aspiration of vomit or secretions. Leaving an unconscious patient on their back (supine) can lead to the tongue falling backward and obstructing the airway, or if they vomit, it could be aspirated into the lungs. Placing the patient in the recovery position allows gravity to help keep the airway open by moving the tongue forward and facilitates the drainage of fluids from the mouth, thereby significantly reducing the risk of airway obstruction and aspiration while awaiting professional medical assistance.

questions.text: Early hospital discharge is defined as the discharge of a newborn earlier than 48 hours following vaginal delivery or 96 hours following cesarean delivery. Of the following, the MOST common reason for re-admission to the hospital within 7 days following an early discharge is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Hyperbilirubinemia. 

Early hospital discharge of newborns, particularly before 48 hours for vaginal delivery or 96 hours for cesarean delivery, increases the likelihood of re-admission due to conditions that typically manifest or peak within the first week of life. Among the given options, neonatal hyperbilirubinemia (jaundice) is overwhelmingly the most common reason for re-hospitalization within 7 days following an early discharge. Bilirubin levels often peak between days 3-5 of life, meaning that many infants discharged early may develop significant jaundice requiring phototherapy or further evaluation once they are at home, thus necessitating re-admission.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man collapses suddenly in a shopping mall. A bystander calls emergency services and starts CPR immediately. Which of the following correctly represents the adult out-of-hospital "Chain of Survival" as per the latest AHA guidelines?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Explanation: The correct sequence in the out-of-hospital chain of survival includes:

1) Early recognition and EMS activation,

2) High-quality CPR,

3) Rapid defibrillation,

4) Advanced life support,

5) Post-cardiac arrest care.

questions.text: A 20 year old female patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide. She is having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Feeding jejunostomy. 

The patient has suffered a severe caustic injury from consuming concentrated sodium hydroxide, resulting in complete dysphagia, meaning they cannot swallow. In such a critical situation, the immediate priority after stabilization is to ensure the patient's nutrition and hydration. A feeding jejunostomy provides a safe and reliable means of delivering enteral nutrition directly into the small intestine, bypassing the severely damaged esophagus. This allows the injured esophagus time to heal, reduces the risk of further injury from oral intake, and supports the patient's overall condition while the long-term management of the esophageal stricture (which may involve reconstructive surgery later) is planned. The other options are either definitive surgical interventions that are too premature for initial management (esophagojejunostomy), or potentially risky/less appropriate as a first step (stent placement, gastrojejunostomy).

questions.text: “Mickey Mouse Sign” during B-mode duplex ultrasound imaging comprises:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Common femoral vein, Common femoral artery and Great Saphenous vein

The "Mickey Mouse Sign" on a B-mode duplex ultrasound refers to the characteristic appearance of the common femoral vein, common femoral artery, and great saphenous vein in the groin region. In this specific transverse view, the common femoral vein forms the "head" of Mickey Mouse, while the common femoral artery and the great saphenous vein appear as the "ears." This anatomical arrangement is a well-recognized landmark in vascular ultrasound, particularly for identifying these vessels and assessing for conditions like deep vein thrombosis or saphenofemoral junction incompetence.

questions.text: A 55 year old patient presented with three days history of right upper abdominal pain, fever with chills. There H/O diarrhoea 1 week back. CT scan showed a hypodense lesion in liver with a size on 10 cm and double ring sign What is the ideal treatment for this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Amoebic abscess with size of > 5cm and Volume of > 300 ml should be treated by percutaneous aspiration with or without pigtail catheter insertion

 Metrogyl and aspiration. The patient's presentation with right upper abdominal pain, fever, chills, a history of diarrhea, and a 10 cm liver lesion with a "double ring sign" on CT scan is highly suggestive of an Amoebic Liver Abscess (ALA). While Metronidazole (Metrogyl) is the cornerstone medical treatment for ALA, for large abscesses (typically over 5 cm or 10 cm, as in this case) or those that are symptomatic and at risk of rupture, percutaneous aspiration (drainage) is often performed in conjunction with antibiotic therapy. This combined approach helps to reduce the abscess burden, alleviate symptoms, prevent complications like rupture, and hasten recovery.

questions.text: 12 months old child can crawl but cannot walk. He can say two words with meaning. He impresses others by waving goodbye. Which area of development is delayed:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

His development is within normal limits.

 At 12 months of age, the ability to crawl is a well-established gross motor skill. While some infants begin to walk independently around their first birthday, the normal developmental window for independent walking extends until 15 to 18 months. Therefore, a 12-month-old who can crawl but not yet walk is within the typical range of gross motor development. Additionally, saying two words with meaning and waving goodbye are appropriate and expected language and social/fine motor milestones for a child of this age. As all reported milestones fall within typical developmental expectations, the child's overall development is considered normal.

questions.text: Young female patient came to emergency with loss of consciousness and CTA given with NCCT Diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

SAH (Subarachnoid Hemorrhage).

The top image, a CTA, clearly demonstrates a saccular aneurysm (marked by the arrow) on a cerebral artery. The bottom image, a non-contrast CT scan of the head, shows high-density (white) material widely distributed within the sulci and basal cisterns, which is characteristic of acute blood accumulating in the subarachnoid space. In a young female presenting with loss of consciousness, the rupture of an intracranial aneurysm causing subarachnoid hemorrhage is a common and critical diagnosis that perfectly aligns with both the angiographic evidence of an aneurysm and the CT evidence of diffuse blood in the subarachnoid space.

questions.text: 48-year-old woman presents with irregular bleeding per vaginum and foul-smelling discharge for 3 months. questions.text: Identify the following pedigree. Which of the following disease is transmitted like this
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Marfans syndrome

The provided pedigree chart demonstrates an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance. This is evidenced by several key features: the trait appears in every generation, affected individuals (such as the father in the first generation) transmit the condition to approximately half of their offspring, and affected fathers can transmit the trait to both their sons and daughters. Among the given options, Marfan syndrome is a well-known genetic disorder that follows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, characterized by defects in connective tissue, thus making it the correct match for the pedigree.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic mutations is most strongly associated with high-grade serous carcinoma of the ovary and fallopian tube?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

BRCA1 mutation

• High-grade serous carcinoma of ovary

• Fallopian tube carcinoma

• Primary peritoneal carcinoma

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presented with swelling in forearm. Radiograph is given below. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Giant Cell tumor

The X-ray image shows an expansile, lytic (bone-destroying) lesion located eccentrically in the distal metaphysis/epiphysis of the ulna, extending close to the articular surface. The patient's age of 22 years is also a crucial clue. This combination of features is highly characteristic of a Giant Cell Tumor (GCT). GCTs typically occur in young adults (20-40 years old) after epiphyseal closure, are classically found in the meta-epiphyseal region of long bones (such as the distal radius, distal femur, proximal tibia, and distal ulna), and appear as eccentric, lytic, expansile lesions that can thin the cortex and extend to the subchondral bone.

questions.text: Term child was born by normal vaginal delivery and there is history rupture of membranes 24 hours before. At 6 hours he is breathing fast and has low temperatures. He has not breastfed since birth RR – 90/min Pulse – 180/min Oxygen saturation – 89% in the air Most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Neonatal sepsis

questions.text: A child presented with a history of a road traffic accident. The finding in the axial CT image is as shown below. It is most commonly caused due to bleeding from
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Middle meningeal artery The given CT image shows the typical biconvex hyperdense lesion not crossing cranial sutures, characteristic of an extradural hemorrhage. It is most commonly due to bleeding from the middle meningeal artery. As the dura mater tends to adhere to the skull, the hematoma collecting between the skull and this dura is seen on CT sections as a biconvex dense area immediately beneath the skull vault, convex towards both the brain and the vault. They tend not to cross the suture lines.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman is found to have increased nuchal translucency and low PAPP-A at 12 weeks. Next best step:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Chorionic villus sampling Explanation: First trimester screen abnormalities warrant CVS (10–13 weeks) for definitive karyotype. Amnio is done after 15 weeks

Chorionic villus sampling (CVS).

The presence of increased nuchal translucency and low PAPP-A at 12 weeks, especially in a 35-year-old pregnant woman, indicates a significantly high risk for fetal chromosomal abnormalities, such as Down syndrome. In such a high-risk scenario, the "next best step" is to pursue a definitive diagnostic test that can confirm or rule out the aneuploidy as early as possible. CVS is an invasive diagnostic procedure that can be performed between 10 to 13 weeks of gestation. It provides a definitive karyotype analysis of the fetal chromosomes, offering a conclusive answer much earlier than amniocentesis (which is typically done after 15 weeks) and a definitive diagnosis unlike NIPT (which is a highly accurate screening test but still requires confirmation for positive results). Therefore, CVS allows for the earliest possible definitive diagnosis, which is crucial for parental counseling and decision-making.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 34 weeks gestation presents with preterm labor. She is contracting regularly, but the cervix is only 1 cm dilated. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for tocolysis at this gestational age?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Nifedipine 

• Nifedipine (a calcium channel blocker) is a first-line tocolytic to delay preterm labor. 

• Other tocolytics: Atosiban (oxytocin receptor antagonist), indomethacin (NSAID – before 32 weeks). 

• Indomethacin should not be used beyond 32 weeks as it will cause premature closure of ductus arteriosus 

• Methylergometrine & carboprost – uterotonics used in postpartum hemorrhage, contraindicated in preterm labor.

questions.text: 2-year-old boy, with history of neonatal jaundice now has abnormal movements of all his limbs, maintains unusual postures. He is hypotonic when asleep. This is suggestive of cerebral palsy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Dyskinetic

Dyskinetic. The history of severe neonatal jaundice in this patient is a crucial clue, as untreated hyperbilirubinemia can lead to kernicterus, causing damage primarily to the basal ganglia. This damage classically manifests as dyskinetic cerebral palsy, characterized by involuntary, uncontrolled, and often fluctuating muscle tone leading to abnormal movements (chorea, athetosis, dystonia) and unusual postures affecting all limbs. The description of the child being "hypotonic when asleep" further supports dyskinetic cerebral palsy, as muscle tone in this type often fluctuates, unlike the persistent high tone seen in spastic forms.

questions.text: A couple has two children affected with tuberous sclerosis. On detailed clinical and laboratory evaluation (including molecular studies) both parents are normal. Which one of the following explains the two affected children in this family?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Germline mosaicism. 

Tuberous Sclerosis is an autosomal dominant disorder. In this scenario, with two affected children but both parents appearing clinically and genetically normal (even with molecular studies), germline mosaicism is the most fitting explanation. Germline mosaicism occurs when a mutation is present in a subset of a parent's germ cells (sperm or egg) but is absent from their somatic cells. This means the parent themselves does not show symptoms and would test negative on standard genetic tests using somatic tissue. However, they can still pass the mutation to multiple offspring through their affected germ cells, explaining how two children in the same family could be affected despite the parents appearing unaffected.

questions.text: All of the following improve the success rate of ECV except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Engaged presenting part If the presenting part is engaged, ECV is less likely to succeed due to restricted mobility. Factors that increase success include: • Relaxed uterus (tocolytics) 
• Multiparity 
• Unengaged breech 
• Adequate liquor

questions.text: A sexually active woman presents with bilateral adnexal tenderness, fever, and cervical motion tenderness. Best next step:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Start empirical antibiotics Explanation: PID is a clinical diagnosis. Empirical treatment should be started immediately to prevent long-term sequelae

Start empirical antibiotics.

The patient's presentation with bilateral adnexal tenderness, fever, and cervical motion tenderness in a sexually active woman is classic for Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID). PID is an infection of the upper female reproductive tract that can lead to severe long-term complications such as infertility, ectopic pregnancy, and chronic pelvic pain if not treated promptly. Due to the potential for these serious sequelae, and given the strong clinical suspicion, it is crucial to initiate empirical broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy immediately without waiting for culture results or imaging, to cover the most common causative organisms (e.g., Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, and anaerobes).

questions.text: 7-month-old female presented with recent onset of diarrhea. There is history of recurrent periods of loose stools, frequent otitis media and upper respiratory infections. There is no history of vomiting and fever. Her celiac serology and HIV elisa are negative. Most likely condition is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

IgA deficiency. 

The 7-month-old female's presentation of recurrent periods of loose stools (diarrhea) alongside frequent otitis media and upper respiratory infections is highly suggestive of a primary immunodeficiency affecting mucosal immunity. Immunoglobulin A (IgA) is the primary antibody found in mucous secretions (e.g., in the gastrointestinal, respiratory, and ear canals) and is crucial for protecting these surfaces from pathogens. Selective IgA deficiency is the most common primary immunodeficiency, and affected individuals frequently experience recurrent infections of the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts, often accompanied by chronic or recurrent diarrhea, which perfectly matches this child's clinical picture after ruling out celiac disease and HIV.

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to induction of labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Transverse lie Induction is absolutely contraindicated in: 

• Transverse lie 

• Placenta previa 

• Classical cesarean scar

 Options A, B, and C may require cautious induction under monitoring

questions.text: Ga PSMA can be used for
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Prostate cancer. 

Ga-PSMA refers to Gallium-68 Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen, a radiotracer used in PET imaging. As its name suggests, PSMA (Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen) is a protein that is highly expressed on the surface of prostate cancer cells, with expression significantly increasing in more aggressive and metastatic forms of the disease. Therefore, Ga-PSMA PET/CT scans are specifically utilized for the detection, staging, and monitoring of prostate cancer, including identifying primary tumors, recurrent disease, and distant metastases, due to its high specificity for PSMA overexpression in these cells.

choices.text: Diagnosis can be made as early as 9 weeks

questions.text: Not true about the following defect is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Diagnosis can be made as early as 9 weeks

Explanation:

Omphalocele is:

• A midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord.

• Covered by a peritoneal sac (unlike gastroschisis).

• Contains bowel ± liver.

Before 11 weeks, physiological midgut herniation is normal → not called omphalocele.

• Persistence of herniated abdominal contents beyond 12 weeks suggests omphalocele.

• Best visualized in sagittal/axial views showing:

• Midline abdominal wall defect

• Herniated contents covered by a membrane (unlike gastroschisis)

• Umbilical cord inserts into the sac

 True Statements:

• a. Commonly associated with structural anomalies
→ Especially cardiac defects, neural tube defects, etc.

• b. Commonly associated with chromosomal abnormalities
→ Especially Trisomy 13, 18, and sometimes 21.

• d. Associated with polyhydramnios
→ Due to impaired swallowing by the fetus.

questions.text: Woman fails to lactate after massive PPH and now has amenorrhea. TSH and cortisol are low. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Sheehan syndrome Explanation: Ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland due to postpartum hemorrhage causes Sheehan syndrome.

The clinical presentation of a woman who fails to lactate after a massive postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) and subsequently develops amenorrhea, along with low TSH and cortisol levels, is highly characteristic of Sheehan syndrome.

Sheehan syndrome is caused by ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland, typically the anterior pituitary, due to severe blood loss and hypovolemic shock during or immediately after childbirth (PPH). During pregnancy, the pituitary gland enlarges, making it more vulnerable to oxygen deprivation if blood flow is compromised. The resulting damage leads to varying degrees of deficiency in the hormones produced by the anterior pituitary.

Failure to lactate: This is often the earliest and most common symptom, due to a deficiency in prolactin.

Amenorrhea: Lack of menstrual periods results from deficiencies in gonadotropins (FSH and LH).

Low TSH and cortisol: These indicate secondary hypothyroidism and secondary adrenal insufficiency, respectively, caused by inadequate production of TSH and ACTH from the damaged pituitary gland.

questions.text: The on this CECT scan point to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

The point to the thalami, which are deep gray nuclei and are therefore hyperdense on CT relative to white matter tracts. Classically, the thalami are not considered part of the basal ganglia. The thalami form the lateral walls of the 3rd ventricle, as nicely seen on this scan.

The posterior part of the thalami is called the pulvinar, and it bulges posteriorly into the atria of the lateral ventricles.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with one child wants long-term contraception and asks for an intrauterine device. She also reports heavy menstrual bleeding. Which of the following is the most appropriate IUD in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system (LNG-IUS) 

Explanation: 

• LNG-IUS (e.g., Mirena) is the best option for women with menorrhagia as it reduces menstrual blood loss and provides long-term contraception (up to 5 years). 

• Copper IUDs (CuT 380A or Multiload) may worsen menstrual bleeding. • Progestasert is outdated and requires yearly replacement — less preferred

questions.text: 9 month old female infant reports with history of not growing fast. She is only the 5th centile for weight and 2nd centile for height. Greatest influence on her growth rate at her age is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Nutrition. 

For a 9-month-old infant, who is in a period of rapid growth and development, adequate nutrition is the single most critical factor influencing growth rate. When an infant is reported as "not growing fast" and is significantly below standard growth centiles (like 5th for height and 2nd for weight), the primary concern is usually insufficient caloric or nutrient intake, or malabsorption. Hormonal influences like growth hormone become more prominent in later childhood, while sex hormones like estrogen and testosterone are irrelevant to linear growth at this early age. Thus, meeting nutritional demands is paramount for healthy infant growth.

questions.text: TTTS is a complication of which type of twin pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS) is a serious complication that can only occur in twin pregnancies where the fetuses share a single, common placenta. This condition is known as monochorionic pregnancy. In monochorionic pregnancies, there are often vascular connections (anastomoses) within the shared placenta, which can lead to an imbalanced blood flow between the twins, resulting in one twin becoming a "donor" and the other a "recipient." Monochorionic diamniotic twins share a placenta but have separate amniotic sacs, and this is the most common and classic type of twin pregnancy susceptible to TTTS. Other types like dichorionic (separate placentas) cannot develop TTTS, and while monoamniotic and conjoined twins are also monochorionic, monochorionic diamniotic is the most frequently encountered scenario for TTTS.

questions.text: 3 weeks old child, exclusively breastfed has yellowing of skin and eyes. Serum bilirubin level is raised and there is increased unconjugated bilirubin. Most likely cause is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Breast milk jaundice

questions.text: Which of the following substances does not cross the placenta?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Heparin Explanation: Heparin is a large, negatively charged molecule and does not cross the placenta

Heparin is the correct option because it is a large, highly negatively charged mucopolysaccharide with a high molecular weight (around 16,000 to 20,000 Daltons for unfractionated heparin). Due to these physicochemical properties, heparin is generally unable to cross the placental barrier in significant amounts. This characteristic makes heparin the anticoagulant of choice for pregnant women requiring antithrombotic therapy, as it provides anticoagulation for the mother without posing a direct risk of anticoagulation or teratogenicity to the fetus.

questions.text: On day 5 post-LSCS, a woman presents with fever and foul-smelling lochia. Uterus is tender. Likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Endometritis Explanation: Postpartum fever + uterine tenderness + foul discharge suggest endometritis, especially after cesarean delivery

Endometritis is the correct diagnosis because the presented symptoms—fever, foul-smelling lochia, and a tender uterus on day 5 post-LSCS—are the classic clinical triad for postpartum endometritis. Endometritis is an infection of the uterine lining (decidua) and is the most common cause of postpartum fever, particularly following a Cesarean section, due to increased risk of bacterial introduction during surgery. The foul-smelling lochia indicates bacterial proliferation within the uterus, and uterine tenderness points directly to inflammation of the uterine wall.

questions.text: This complication is seen in which type of twin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

MCDA

TRAP – Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion Sequence

Definition: 

A rare complication of monochorionic twin pregnancy where a malformed “acardiac” twin is perfused in reverse by the normal “pump” twin via abnormal arterial-to-arterial placental anastomoses.

 Key Features:

• Occurs only in monochorionic twins

• Acardiac twin:

• No heart or head (severely malformed)

• Receives deoxygenated blood in reverse via umbilical artery

• Pump twin:

• Normal anatomy

• At risk of high-output cardiac failure due to perfusing both twins

choices.text: Streak gonads with absent uterus on ultrasound
Normal karyotype with mosaicism in somatic cells

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with short stature, webbed neck, and lack of breast development. She has not attained menarche. On examination, she has shield chest, widely spaced nipples, and higharched palate. Her FSH is markedly elevated. Which of the following findings is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Bicuspid aortic valve on echocardiography 

Explanation: 

• Turner syndrome (45,X or mosaic variants) presents with: 

• Short stature, webbed neck, shield chest 

• Primary amenorrhea, streak ovaries 

• Elevated FSH/LH due to ovarian failure 

• Normal uterus on USG

• Bicuspid aortic valve and coarctation of aorta are common cardiac anomalies 

• A) Elevated 17-OHP

? CAH (not Turner) 

• B) Absent uterus - Müllerian agenesis (MRKH), not Turner 

• D) Mosaicism is possible, but doesn’t exclude classic features like cardiac anomaly

questions.text: What is the finding in the above antenatal USG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Anencephaly 

Explanation:

• Anencephaly is a neural tube defect characterized by the absence of the cranial vault and most of the brain tissue.

• On ultrasound:

o Absent cranial calvarium

o Orbits may be visible ("frog-eye" appearance)

o Spinal column is visible but the skull vault above orbits is absent

• In the image:

o The arrow points to the area where the skull vault is absent

o There is exposed brain tissue or absent brain structures

o The vertebral column is intact, ruling out total craniorachischisis

choices.text: Middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA-PSV)

questions.text: The most sensitive marker of fetal anemia on Doppler is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

MCA-PSV Explanation: Increased MCA-PSV (>1.5 MoM) indicates fetal anemia due to decreased blood viscosity and compensatory vasodilation.

The middle cerebral artery peak systolic velocity (MCA-PSV) is considered the most sensitive and reliable non-invasive Doppler marker for fetal anemia. When a fetus becomes anemic, its blood viscosity decreases. In response to this, the fetal cardiovascular system undergoes compensatory changes, including a redistribution of blood flow to vital organs like the brain, to ensure adequate oxygen delivery. This cerebral vasodilation and decreased blood viscosity lead to an increase in blood flow velocity in the middle cerebral artery, which can be measured as an elevated MCA-PSV. A value greater than 1.5 multiples of the median (MoM) for gestational age is a strong indicator of moderate to severe fetal anemia, prompting further investigation or intervention.

questions.text: 14-year-old girl presents with primary amenorrhea and clitoromegaly. Karyotype is 46,XX. Testosterone is high. Most likely enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

21-hydroxylase Explanation: Most common cause of CAH is 21- hydroxylase deficiency, causing excess androgens, virilization, and salt-wasting in some cases

This diagnosis best explains the combination of symptoms in a 14-year-old 46,XX girl: primary amenorrhea, clitoromegaly, and high testosterone. 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common form of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH). In this condition, the adrenal glands cannot produce sufficient cortisol, leading to an overproduction of ACTH. This excess ACTH then shunts steroid precursors towards the androgen synthesis pathway, resulting in excessive adrenal androgen production. These high androgen levels cause virilization (like clitoromegaly) and disrupt the normal ovarian cycle, leading to primary amenorrhea in genetically female individuals. While other enzyme deficiencies can also cause androgen excess, 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most prevalent cause presenting with this clinical picture.

questions.text: Savita, a 7 years old girl, presents with recurrent onset of genu valgum and difficulty in walking. On X-ray there is metaphyseal widening and osteoporosis. Serum Ca 9mg/d, serum phosphorus 2.5mg/dL and Alkaline Phosphatase 30 KAU. PTH level is normal. Probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Hypophosphatemic rickets

This diagnosis is strongly supported by Savita's lab results. Hypophosphatemic rickets, often genetic (like X-linked hypophosphatemia), is characterized by the kidneys' inability to reabsorb phosphate effectively, leading to low serum phosphorus. Crucially, unlike nutritional rickets, serum calcium and PTH levels are typically normal because the primary defect is in phosphate handling, not calcium or vitamin D metabolism. Savita's normal calcium, low phosphorus, and elevated alkaline phosphatase (indicating bone turnover due to the rickets) perfectly align with the biochemical profile of hypophosphatemic rickets.

choices.text: Blood is still flowing the pulmonary artery to the aorta as in the fetal circulation
Chest wall and ribs are too complaint
There is ventilation perfusion mismatch from surfactant deficiency

questions.text: A 32 years gestation,33 weeks gestation female infant delivered by caesarean section, birth weight 1.9 kg, no resuscitation is required.There is distress with respiratory rate of 70 breaths/min, retractions present. Respiratory support is required with CPAP (Continuous positive airway pressure) and 45% oxygen is required. Most likely cause of oxygen therapy and respiratory support is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

There is ventilation perfusion mismatch from surfactant deficiency. The patient is a 33-week gestation premature infant, a demographic highly susceptible to Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS). RDS in preterm infants is primarily caused by an insufficient amount or function of pulmonary surfactant, which is vital for preventing the collapse of alveoli. Without adequate surfactant, widespread alveolar collapse (atelectasis) occurs, leading to large areas of the lung being perfused with blood but not properly ventilated. This creates a significant ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, resulting in severe hypoxemia and the characteristic signs of respiratory distress (tachypnea, retractions) requiring oxygen therapy and positive pressure support like CPAP to keep the alveoli open and improve gas exchange.

questions.text: A woman with chronic pelvic pain undergoes TVS showing an ovarian cyst with “ground glass” echogenicity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Endometrioma

Explanation: Classic ultrasound appearance of endometrioma is homogenous, low-level internal echoes (“ground glass”) due to old blood

choices.text: Implantation of blastocyst into the endometrium

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman conceives after natural intercourse. Which of the following events is most likely to occur around 6–7 days post-ovulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A) Capacitation of sperm – occurs in the female reproductive tract shortly after ejaculation, before fertilization (within hours). 

B) Fertilization – takes place in the ampulla of the fallopian tube, typically around Day 14 of a 28-day cycle (i.e., within 24 hours of
ovulation). 

C) Cleavage – begins as the zygote travels down the fallopian tube, from Day 1 to 4 postfertilization.

D) Implantation – usually occurs 6–7 days after ovulation/fertilization, when the blastocyst embeds into the endometrium, marking the start of pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is the surgery of choice for a 35-year-old woman with uterine prolapse who wishes to preserve fertility?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sling surgery (sacrohysteropexy) 

• Sacrohysteropexy: Uses mesh to suspend uterus from sacral promontory, preserves fertility. 

• Fothergill’s (Manchester) involves cervical amputation — not fertility-preserving. • Le Fort’s and vaginal hysterectomy eliminate
reproductive potential.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with abdominal bloating and pelvic mass. Imaging suggests a solid-cystic ovarian mass with ascites. Which tumor marker is most appropriate for diagnosis and monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CA-125 CA-125 is elevated in epithelial ovarian carcinoma, especially serous subtype, and used for diagnosis, prognosis, and recurrence monitoring in postmenopausal women. (AFP and ?-hCG are germ cell markers; LDH is used in dysgerminoma.)

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image is contraindicated in which of the following condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Prematurity

ECV is contraindicated in the following conditions:

• Prematurity (<37 weeks): because spontaneous version can still occur, and performing ECV may introduce unnecessary risks.

• Multiple pregnancy

• Placenta previa

• Any contraindication to vaginal delivery (e.g., classical cesarean scar, uterine anomaly)

• Unstable lie

• Ruptured membranes

• Abnormal CTG

questions.text: Woman in second stage of labor with fetal distress at +2 station, vertex position. Best instrument to use:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Wrigley’s forceps Explanation: Wrigley’s forceps are used for low/outlet forceps delivery (station +2 or more) and are preferred in fetal distress.
